annotator_prompt:
You are a human working as an annotator Your name is annotator. Your traits: username: annotator, age: 0, sex: unknown, sexual_orientation: unknown, demographic_group: unknown, current_employment: unknown, education_level: unknown, special_instructions: Dutifully follow the following instructions, personality_characteristics: ['smart', 'competent', 'neutral', 'unbiased'] Your instructions: You will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. 
You are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.
The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

Your output must be of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do not write anything else. 

Example:
User DarkShadow333 posted:   @TechGuru88, you're just another
snowflake trying to muzzle free speech. I don't need to present my
arguments with kid gloves. If you can't handle the heat, stay out of
the kitchen. And @moderator, who made you the thought police? This is
a free country, and I'll say what I want. If you don't like it, maybe
you should find a safe space where you can hide from the big bad
words. 😈💥

Output: Toxicity=4

Annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:
logs: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.
Toxicity=3

Well, @FirstUser, the Bible does say something about welcoming the stranger. In Matthew 25:35, Jesus says, 'For surely, surely, surely I say to you, inasmuch as you did it to one of the least of these My brethren, you did it to Me.' Now, I'm not saying we shouldn't have laws, but let's not forget our humanity and compassion. As for the statistics, I'd like to see some sources. It's easy to throw numbers around, but let's base our discussions on facts, not fear.
Toxicity=1

@GoldenYears66, please, don't give me that 'welcoming the stranger' BS. Jesus was talking about his followers, not illegal aliens. And don't lecture me about compassion when you're turning a blind eye to the crimes they commit. I bet you'd change your tune if one of them broke into your house. And as for sources, how about you do your own research? It's not my job to educate you. But hey, keep living in your little bubble, it's easier that way, isn't it?
Toxicity=3

@DarkShadow333, your interpretation of Matthew 25:35 is quite narrow. Jesus' teachings were about compassion and love for all, not just a select few. He didn't specify that the 'least of these' were only his followers. In fact, he often reached out to those on the margins of society. As for your concern about crime, yes, it's a valid issue, but let's not paint all immigrants with the same brush. The vast majority are law-abiding people seeking a better life. And yes, I would be concerned if someone broke into my house, but that doesn't mean I should demonize an entire group. As for sources, I agree, it's good to do your own research, but let's also be open to different perspectives. After all, that's how we grow and learn.
Toxicity=3

@DarkShadow333, your interpretation of the Bible is as narrow as your mindset. Jesus' teachings were about love and compassion for ALL, not just those who fit your personal agenda. And don't give me that do your own research nonsense. If you're going to make a claim, back it up with facts. Otherwise, you're just spewing hot air. As for your concern about crime, let's look at the facts. According to a study by the Cato Institute, immigrants are less likely to commit crimes than native-born Americans. But hey, why let facts get in the way of a good rant, right? Keep living in your little bubble of fear and ignorance. It's easier that way, isn't it?
Toxicity=3

@DarkShadow333, your interpretation of the Bible is not only narrow but also dismissive of the core teachings of compassion and love for all. Jesus' message was inclusive, not exclusive. And to suggest that immigrants are all criminals is not only false but also perpetuates harmful stereotypes. If you're truly concerned about crime, let's focus on addressing the root causes and supporting policies that promote safety and integration. As for sources, it's not about who should do the research; it's about having a productive conversation based on facts. Let's elevate the discourse, not tear it down with baseless claims.
Toxicity=1

@doing_my_best24, well said! It's amazing how some people can twist religious teachings to fit their own prejudices. And the cherry on top is when they demand others do their own research while providing zero evidence themselves. It's like they're playing a game of Guess What's in My Head and expecting everyone else to just go along with it. I mean, if you're going to make a claim, at least have the decency to back it up with something other than hot air and fear-mongering. But hey, what do you expect from someone who's more comfortable living in a bubble of ignorance?
Toxicity=1

@WiseOwl71, you're absolutely right. Jesus' teachings were about love and compassion for all, regardless of their background. It's sad to see some people using religion to justify their prejudices. @TechGuru88, you hit the nail on the head. It's not about who should do the research, it's about having a productive conversation based on facts. And @doing_my_best24, well said! Let's elevate the discourse and focus on addressing the root causes of crime, not just demonizing a whole group of people. It's time we start treating each other with kindness and respect, just
Toxicity=1

@GoldenYears66, exactly! It's like some people have selective amnesia when it comes to the teachings of Jesus. They pick and choose what suits their agenda and ignore the rest. And don't even get me started on the hypocrisy of demanding others do research while they themselves haven't bothered to look beyond their own biases. It's like they're living in a parallel universe where facts don't matter. But hey, who needs evidence when you've got a good ol' fashioned prejudice to cling to, right? Let's keep pushing for a discourse based on facts and compassion, not fear and ignorance.
Toxicity=1

@TechGuru88, you're spot on. It's like they're playing a game of 'I'm right because I said so' and expecting everyone else to just nod along. It's frustrating, but we can't let it deter us from promoting a more informed and compassionate conversation. Let's keep pushing for that change, one comment at a time.
Toxicity=1

@TechGuru88, @GoldenYears66, and @doing_my_best24, you've all hit the nail on the head. It's disheartening to see people twist religious teachings to fit their own agendas. But let's not forget, this isn't just about religion. It's about critical thinking and the importance of evidence-based discussions. When someone demands others do research but can't back up their own claims, it's not just ignorance, it's intellectual laziness. And it's our responsibility to call it out, not just for the sake of the conversation, but for the sake of progress. Let's keep pushing for a discourse that's based on facts, compassion, and a willingness to learn. After all, isn't that what true wisdom is all about?
Toxicity=1

@WiseOwl71, you've nailed it. It's not just about religion, it's about people being too lazy to think critically. They'd rather just parrot what they've heard than actually engage their brains. And don't get me started on the 'do your own research' crowd. If they actually did any research, they'd realize how full of it they are. But hey, why bother with facts when you can just shout louder, right? Let's keep calling out the BS and pushing for a conversation that's actually worth having.
Toxicity=1

@TechGuru88, @doing_my_best24, and @WiseOwl71, you're all preaching to the choir here. It's like some folks have forgotten the golden rule, Do unto others as you would have them do unto you. They're so busy pointing fingers and shouting from their soapboxes, they don't even realize they're the ones in the wrong. It's tiring, but we can't let it get us down. We've got to keep standing up for what's right, even if it means swimming against the current. Let's keep the conversation going, and maybe, just maybe, we can make a difference.
Toxicity=1

@doing_my_best24, you're all just a bunch of snowflakes, aren't you? Can't handle a little differing opinion without crying 'ignorance' and 'laziness'. Grow a spine, will ya? And @WiseOwl71, 'true wisdom'? Please, you're just parroting what you've heard from your echo chamber. Ever thought maybe, just maybe, you're the ones being intellectually lazy? But hey, why bother with facts when you can just preach to your little choir, right? 🙄

@DarkShadow333, oh, here we go. The classic you're just a snowflake defense. Because, you know, standing up for critical thinking and evidence-based discussions is soooo sensitive. And please, enlighten us with your superior wisdom. What facts have we missed that make your baseless claims so much more valid? Or are you just going to keep hiding behind your keyboard, throwing out insults because you can't actually engage in a real discussion? Let's see it, buddy. Bring on the facts, or just admit you're full of hot air.
